content.description: Sit start at the far right end, move left up the slopey shelf feature (crux), and the surmount the slab above to a highball topout.
content.location: Start on the far right end on the backside of the boulder roughly about 15 feet right of the fixed rope hanging down.

content.description: Climb up the less-than-all-there face to the top. Be careful of the tree.
content.location: This is on the back side of the block right of where the climb off is.

content.description: Sit start the flake, and move straight up the steep slab on marginal holds and good footwork.
content.location: Start on the backside of the boulder roughly about 8-10 feet left of the fixed rope hanging down.

content.description: Stand start the steep, slopey arête moving up and right to top out.
content.location: Start about 4-5 feet right of the problem Flawless.

content.description: Start sitting as low as possible on the steep, slopey arête and finish up the thin finger crack. One of the best V5s in the Commonwealth.
content.location: This ascends the overhanging cylinder on the steepest side of the boulder.

content.description: Follow up the flake, following up a nice slabby face. You can get fancy with it by traversing out the the left.
content.location: This is in the middle of the block when you walk down the hill from Little Agassiz.

content.description: Start with a good left undercling and a high right with a good foot. Bump up to a good jug and mantle over the lip. Then top out is a little crusty.
content.location: This on the left side of the overhung face.

content.description: Start in slightly left of the arete on the tallest side of the block. Follow up a right-facing crack to the top. Getting off the ground is the crux.
content.location: This is on the tallest face, just left of the arete.

content.description: Sit start the steep left bulge/face on the obvious steepest side of the Egg Boulder. Without using the big knob on the left, move up and right to a highball top out. This problem replaces the original route known as Egg Right.
content.location: This is on the left side of the overhung face.

content.description:
This is a huge, house-sized block hidden at the bottom of the east side of the hill of Little Agassiz. It is currently under-utilized but is ready to be worked. There are a handful of fun problems on this block, none really all that hard but some that certainly take a little bit bravery if bouldered. There are TR anchors on the highest point with a rope to either climb up or off. I will assume the anchors were placed to protect from a high fall onto a bad landing. 

  I can't say this block is a destination in and of it self like the little agassiz area up the hill, but certainly might become part of a fun circuit if the several other blocks that still lay hidden got some work.
